Award.AwardTitle: Model Development and Model Validation for Pandemic Influenza
Award.AbstractNarration:
Influenza has long been known to be more prevalent in winter, although it is unknown whether this is due to increased contact rates during the school year, or due to environmental effects on the transmissibility of the virus. This seasonality is responsible for the spring/autumn dual wave nature that can be seen in pandemic influenza. Current models of influenza that attempt to incorporate the seasonality of the disease into the model generally assume a harmonically forced infection rate. However, our preliminary exploratory studies have shown that a periodically forced infection rate leads to chaotic dynamics, and that different assumptions of the nature of the periodicity can thus lead to dramatic changes in the predictions of the short term dynamics of the spread of the disease in a population, particularly in the case of pandemic influenza. Using an incorrect assumption for the time behavior of the infection rate in the model can thus be quite damaging if the models are employed to assist policy-makers in disease control and interventions in the event of a new pandemic outbreak.

Our research thus aims to understand the short-term dynamics of pandemic influenza through the development of realistic models that accurately describe population dynamics and the seasonal nature of the disease. We model the disease through ordinary differential equations (ODE's). We will examine the sensitivity of the model predictions to changes in the model parameters; because of the chaotic nature of the system, such studies are important to ascertain the robustness of the model predictions when disease intervention strategies (such as vaccination campaigns) are assessed using the model. Our work will shed new light on the complex short term dynamics possible with pandemic influenza, which has hitherto not been well studied. Through a hierarchical advancement of model complexity, we will identify the most appropriate and pragmatic models, avoiding the development of overly complex and abstruse methods. Further, by explicitly linking the mathematical models with existing data, we ensure that the models will produce reliable results for use in the development of public health policy in pandemic preparedness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematical models can be very helpful for understanding the transmission dynamics of infectious diseases and for comparing the effectiveness of various disease control strategies. However, the reliability of a model for generating accurate predictions depend critically on the assumptions used in the model, which are necessary in order for the model to be amendable for analysis. The project focuses on the development and study of models and modeling approaches by relaxing particular assumptions, which are commonly used in disease models but may not be appropriate for some specific infectious diseases.

The model assumptions we aim to relax include: (i) replacing the constant rate of disease transmission by seasonally forced transmission rate for modeling pandemic influenza, and (ii) generalizing the homogeneous or random mixing to allow for preferential mixing, where the preference can be structured by individual's age, spatial location, gender, and activity level. We incorporated these heterogeneities in the models we studied while keeping the models manageable.  Our model results demonstrated that, in many cases, the models can generate insights into the disease dynamics that are dramatically different from those generated by models without these heterogeneities. For example, for pandemic influenza, the models with a seaonally variable infection rate show the time of disease introduction (the first case) and starting time of control programs (vaccination and/or medication treatment) can lead to very different outcomes regarding (a) when the second wave will be reached; (b) how large the peak size of the second wave and the final epidemic size will be; and (c) whether or not an adverse effect may occur, i.e., a higher level of treatment will lead to an increased final epidemic size. Specifically, using a periodic SIR model with vaccination and medication treatment, we found that vaccination and or antivirals could sometimes dramatically adversely impact the final size of a pandemic, and that vaccination during a spring wave could cause an autumn wave to appear where none would otherwise have occurred. Using an age-structured SIR model with periodic transmission rate, we study the effect of the length and timing of school closures on the progression of a pandemic. The model results demonstrate that the final size of a pandemic may actually be larger if the school closures are poorly timed during a late spring wave.

We have also developed a modeling framework to capture the observed preferential mixing patterns relevant to the spread of infectious diseases. We demonstrated the role of the preferential mixing associated with parent-children or grantparent-grandchildren interactions, and student contacts within school or among different schools. It could be critical to incoporate such mixing functions into a model for the control and prevention of outbreaks of childhood diseases in a network of connected schools. Another commonly used simplifying assumption in disease models is about the stage distribution of the infectious period, particularly, the exponential (for continuous-time models) and geometric (for discrete-time models) distributions. However, these unrealistic assumptions have been shown to generate biased or misleading evaluations of intervention control measures in some cases. We developed and analyzed models with arbitrarily distributed disease stages. Model results and simulations highlight the impact of the choices of disease stage distribution on the relative importance of various disease control measures.
